text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Israeli newspapers on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HAARETZ
- Washington's impression: Palestinian President Yasser Arafat not interested in security coordiation with Israel.
- Palestinian security official Jibril Rajoub: Israeli army officers have been dragged into being pawns of politicians.
- Bank of Israel Governor Jacob Frenkel: If we don't maintain the planned deficit, Israel's credit rating may be harmed.
- Income tax authorities mull cancellation of income credits to working women.
- American pharmaceutical companies prefer Israel as site for clinical trials on humans.
JERUSALEM POST
- Arab foreign ministers agree to renew boycott against Israel.
- Compromise still being sought on bill on Israel recognising only Orthodox conversions to Judaism.
- Man with transplanted kidney gets new liver in medical first.
YEDIOTH AHRONOTH
- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to go to Washington to press United States to intervene in crisis with Palestinians.
- Ultraorthodox Jews threaten to bolt ruling coalition if "Conversion Law" not approved.
- Israeli army reinstitutes West Bank "Nablus Brigade" - unit that was disbanded at cost of millions of dollars.
- Daughter-in-law of Foreign Minister David Levy demanding alimony, compensation three months after marrying his son.
MAARIV
- Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak: peace process has deteriorated to its lowest point since 1977.
- Frenkel: Unemployment to rise, economic growth to slow.
- Interim reading of Conversion Law today in parliament.
- Palestinian security men abduct Israeli citizen in territory controlled by Jewish state.
GLOBES
- Arab foreign ministers: resume the boycott against Israel. Oman announces it will close representation in Israel.
- Bank Leumi 1996 profits up 24.4 percent relative to 1995.
- Frenkel "If senior bank executives' salaries will affect the wage structure of the economy - we will deal with this big time".
